conclusion: The graph of x(t) is a continuously decreasing, smooth curve from +10 m at t = 0 s to â€“10 m at t = 4 s.
Because the slope dx/dt is everywhere negative, the particle always moves in the negative-x direction (never turns back).
The magnitude of the slope is small at first, increases steadily, and is largest near t = 4 s; thus the particle starts slowly, speeds up steadily, and is fastest near t = 4 s.
The magnitude of the slope |dx/dt| starts below 5 m/s, grows through 5 m/s exactly once, and then becomes larger than 5 m/s for the rest of the interval.
The equation |dx/dt| = 5 m/s has only one solution in the range 0 s < t < 4 s.
Between 0 s and 4 s the particle always moves in the negative-x direction and its speed increases continuously.
The speed equals 5 m/s at one and only one instant in this interval.
